message: What makes it different from Forrst and Dribbble is that members post links to what they're reading and finding online and the most popular links appear on the main page.
"A community for programmers and designers to share and learn."
Tagline is 5x too long. How's about this:
My startup is Talentopoly.com. It's tagline is: "A community for programmers, designers, and IT Professionals to share their work, get feedback, post links and learn."

The emphasis is on posting links to articles, blogs posts, tutorials and resources (icon sets, templates). It's not trying to be a place for designers to post their latest design work to get feedback or for a programmer to ask others to help troubleshoot his code.
So I want to craft a tagline that reflects this. Any thoughts?
What describes it @krainboltgreene? The current brief description on Talentopoly?

I definitely agree that Forrst has this feature. You've always been able to post links on Forrst. So it could conceivably describe many sites. What I'm aiming for is a site where links are the sole focus.
Awesome, thanks @micrypt, that's the hope.
I find myself wanting something like this.
That's why I think getting the right brief description is key. What do you think the description should be @micrypt, @krainboltgreene, @tarikh?
I like that as the tagline. Thanks.

Maybe tagline wasn't the right word to use. What I'm trying to work on is the brief description. This is the description that new users are presented with on the landing page of Talentopoly.com. How should that description be worded to convey the concepts outlined above?
If the standard for content shared is kept high, I'd definitely find that useful.
@jaredbrown Preeeeeeetty sure that describes Forrst exactly.
"members post links to what they're reading and finding online and the most popular links appear on the main page."
Another critical difference is that posts on Talentopoly are public. Only members can post, like, and comment. But anyone is welcome to come check out the content.

I find that a lot of good links on Forrst and Twitter get buried in the stream and aren't that easy to find. Also the number of posts on Forrst that are links is far less than the number of posts that are questions and snaps in my experience. Is this what you've found to be true @krainboltgreene?

Forrst is a deluge of stuff I'm not interested in. HN's too political. Digg's missing the social element (same as Reddit), Twitter means I get to inadvertently discover people's food preferences also...
@micrypt you're hitting the nail on the head!
It's hard to convey the exact intention of the site though as comparisons to Forrst, HackerNews, Digg's Technology category, Reddit programming, Twitter etc. are always going to be made.
If you want an invite @micrypt just request one on the site I'll get you right in so you can have a look around.
@jaredbrown Request sent.
Thanks @suujin
I second @tarikh - to paraphrase Timberlake/Parker, it's cleaner. By the way, mind the difference between "its" and "it's" in your first post - "it's" means "it is," whereas "its" is possessive.
I'm running an experiment on HN today to see if the current description for Talentopoly can be optimized by the community. http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=2250042
Upvoted. The results should be interesting.
@jaredbrown http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=2252152
I think the tagline needs to make it clear it's only links. I was seriously disappointed when I discovered it wasn't really sharing my work, it was just sharing links to my work.

@awfy I agree. That is my intention with this new description is to make that clear. And links can be to your work, to something you just read, a blog post you wrote, a tutorial you think is great, an icon set that just went on sale, an amazing deal at AppSumo, news of changes to the CSS3 spec, etc.
